member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.EmulatorDetection
member.summary: Specifies whether or not an emulator configuration should be present and whether or not it should be used. Emulator configuration is usually specified through environment variables.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.EmulatorDetection.None
member.summary: Ignores the presence or absence of emulator configuration.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.EmulatorDetection.ProductionOnly
member.summary: Always connect to the production servers, but throw an exception if an emulator configuration is detected that would suggest connecting to an emulator is expected.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.EmulatorDetection.EmulatorOnly
member.summary: Always connect to the emulator, throwing an exception if no emulator configuration is detected.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.EmulatorDetection.EmulatorOrProduction
member.summary: Connect to the emulator if an emulator configuration is detected, or production otherwise. This is a convenient option, but risks damage to production databases or running up unexpected bills if tests are accidentally run in production due to the emulator configuration being absent unexpectedly. (Using separate projects for production and testing is a best practice for preventing the first issue, but may be unrealistic for small or hobby projects.)

member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer
member.summary: Simple but strict JSON tokenizer, rigidly following RFC 7159.

remarks.para: This tokenizer is stateful, and only returns "useful" tokens - names, values etc. It does not create tokens for the separator between names and values, or for the comma between values. It validates the token stream as it goes - so callers can assume that the tokens it produces are appropriate. For example, it would never produce "start object, end array."

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.FromTextReader(System.IO.TextReader)
member.summary: Creates a tokenizer that reads from the given text reader.

member.summary: Pushes a new container type onto the stack and validates that we don't violate the maximum depth.

member.summary: Peeks at the next token in the stream, without changing the visible state.
member.returns: The next token in the stream.

member.summary: Skips the value we're about to read. This must only be called immediately after reading a property name. If the value is an object or an array, the complete object/array is skipped.

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.Next
member.summary: Returns the next JSON token in the stream.
member.exception: This method is called after an EndDocument token has been returned
The input text does not comply with RFC 7159
member.returns: The next token in the stream.

member.summary: Reads an escaped character. It is assumed that the leading backslash has already been read.

member.summary: Reads an escaped Unicode 4-nybble hex sequence. It is assumed that the leading \u has already been read.

member.summary: Consumes a text-only literal, throwing an exception if the read text doesn't match it. It is assumed that the first letter of the literal has already been read.

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.ValidateAndModifyStateForValue(System.String)
member.summary: Validates that we're in a valid state to read a value (using the given error prefix if necessary) and changes the state to the appropriate one, e.g. ObjectAfterColon to ObjectAfterProperty.

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.PopContainer
member.summary: Pops the top-most container, and sets the state to the appropriate one for the end of a value in the parent container.

member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State
member.summary: Possible states of the tokenizer.

remarks.para: This is a flags enum purely so we can simply and efficiently represent a set of valid states for checking.

Each is documented with an example, where ^ represents the current position within the text stream. The examples all use string values, but could be any value, including nested objects/arrays. The complete state of the tokenizer also includes a stack to indicate the contexts (arrays/objects). Any additional notional state of "AfterValue" indicates that a value has been completed, at which point there's an immediate transition to ExpectedEndOfDocument, ObjectAfterProperty or ArrayAfterValue.
These states were derived manually by reading RFC 7159 carefully.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.StartOfDocument
member.summary: ^ { "foo": "bar" } Before the value in a document. Next states: ObjectStart, ArrayStart, "AfterValue"

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ExpectedEndOfDocument
member.summary: { "foo": "bar" } ^ After the value in a document. Next states: ReaderExhausted

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ReaderExhausted
member.summary: { "foo": "bar" } ^ (and already read to the end of the reader) Terminal state.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ObjectStart
member.summary: { ^ "foo": "bar" } Before the *first* property in an object. Next states: "AfterValue" (empty object) ObjectBeforeColon (read a name)

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ObjectBeforeColon
member.summary: { "foo" ^ : "bar", "x": "y" } Next state: ObjectAfterColon

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ObjectAfterColon
member.summary: { "foo" : ^ "bar", "x": "y" } Before any property other than the first in an object. (Equivalently: after any property in an object) Next states: "AfterValue" (value is simple) ObjectStart (value is object) ArrayStart (value is array)

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ObjectAfterProperty
F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ObjectAfterComma
member.summary: { "foo":"bar", ^ "x":"y" } Read the comma after the previous property, so expecting another property. This is like ObjectStart, but closing brace isn't valid here Next state: ObjectBeforeColon.

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ArrayStart
member.summary: [ ^ "foo", "bar" ] Before the *first* value in an array. Next states: "AfterValue" (read a value) "AfterValue" (end of array; will pop stack)

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ArrayAfterValue
member.summary: [ "foo" ^ , "bar" ] After any value in an array, so expecting either a comma or end-of-array Next states: ArrayAfterComma or "AfterValue"

member.name: F:Google.Api.Gax.Json.JsonTokenizer.State.ArrayAfterComma
member.summary: [ "foo", ^ "bar" ] After a comma in an array, so there *must* be another value (simple or complex). Next states: "AfterValue" (simple value), StartObject, StartArray

member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.PagedAsyncEnumerable`2
member.summary: An asynchronous sequence of resources obtained via API responses. Application code can treat this as a simple sequence (with API calls automatically being made lazily as more results are required), or call to retrieve one API response at a time, potentially with additional information.
member.typeparam: The API response type. Each response contains a page of resources.
The resource type contained within the response.

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.PagedAsyncEnumerable`2.AsRawResponses
member.summary: Returns the sequence of raw API responses, each of which contributes a page of resources to this sequence.
member.returns: An asynchronous sequence of raw API responses, each containing a page of resources.

member.name: M:Google.Api.Gax.PagedAsyncEnumerable`2.ReadPageAsync(System.Int32,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Eagerly (but asynchronously) reads a single page of results with a fixed maximum size. The returned page is guaranteed to have that many results, unless there is no more data available.
member.remarks: "Natural" pages returned by the API may contain a smaller number of resources than requested. For example, a request for a page with 100 resources may return a page with 80 resources but a next page token for more to be retrieved. This is suitable for batch-processing, but not for user-visible paging such as in a web application, where fixed-size pages are expected. This method may make more than one API call in order to fill the page, but after the page has been returned, all the data will have been loaded. (In particular, iterating over the items in the page multiple times will not make any further requests.)
member.param: The page size. Must be greater than 0.
A token to cancel the operation.
member.returns: An asynchronous operation, the result of which is a page of resources.

remarks.para: Templates use a subset of the syntax of the API platform. See https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis/blob/master/google/api/http.proto for details of the API platform.

member.summary: Determine the metadata host to use. In order of priority, this will use: - GCE_METADATA_HOST environment variable, if set and non-empty - METADATA_EMULATOR_HOST environment variable, if set and non-empty. This is the undocumented but the de-facto mechanism for using an emulator. - The hard-coded IP address of "169.254.169.254". We use the IP address rather than the IP name to avoid a DNS lookup, which can cause intermittent failures.

member.summary: Asynchronously repeatedly calls the specified polling action, delaying between calls, until a given condition is met in the response.

member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.PollSettings
member.summary: Settings controlling repeated polling, for example when waiting for a long-running operation to complete.

member.name: P:Google.Api.Gax.PollSettings.Expiration

member.name: P:Google.Api.Gax.PollSettings.Delay
member.summary: The delay between RPC calls when fetching the operation status. This is never negative. There is no exponential backoff between calls; the same delay is used for each call.
member.remarks: This is the delay between the a successful RPC response being received and the next RPC request being sent.

member.name: T:Google.Api.Gax.TemplatedResourceName
member.summary: Class for representing and working with resource names.

remarks.para: A resource name is represented by a , an assignment of resource IDs to parameters in the template, and an optional service name. This class allows the service name and resource IDs to be modified, but only within the same template.
